newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 29.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Friday.
- The government will engage in intensive Anglo-Irish activity in the next few days to salvage the damaged prospect of a renewed IRA ceasefire over the Christmas period.
- As the number of cases of BSE continues to rise, the Minister for Agriculture, Ivan Yates has allocated 5 million Irish pounds for reasearch into the disease.
- As the pound surged again against the deutschmark on Thursday, business organisation warnmed of ever-tighter margins for Irish exporters to Germany.
- Police are to deploy the "stinger" spike system to deflate the tyres of stolen cars during pursuit operations.
- Over 400 heart surgery patients at the Mater Hospital are to be tested for hepatitis B after being operated on by a doctor who has tested positive for the virus.
- Finance Minister Ruairi Quinn attempted to restrain rising pay expectations last night and stressed that it was important that "people did not lose the run of themselves" in the current pay talks.
- The government would have had an extra 400 million Irish pounds for tax cuts in its three budgets if it had met its own spending targets.
- A new chief executive is expected to be appointed at food firm Golden Vale on Friday evening. Jim Murphy, current operations director with The Cheese Company, is believed to be the front runner.
